conditions.description: Progressive muscle weakness and degeneration due to genetic mutations.
Degenerative disease affecting motor neurons, leading to muscle weakness.
Autoimmune disorder causing muscle weakness and fatigue.
Autoimmune condition that can result in muscle weakness and paralysis.
Widespread muscle pain and tenderness often accompanied by fatigue.
Inflammation of muscle tissue leading to muscle pain and weakness.
Painful, involuntary muscle contractions often caused by muscle fatigue.
Pain and discomfort from overstretching or tearing muscles.
Autoimmune disease that can cause muscle stiffness and spasticity.
Neurodegenerative condition leading to muscle rigidity and stiffness.
Inflammatory condition that may result in joint and muscle stiffness.
Stiffness may accompany muscle cramps or spasms.
Involuntary muscle twitching without an underlying disease.
Muscle twitching can be an early symptom of ALS.
Muscle twitching may occur in drug-induced lupus.
Tingling and muscle twitching may result from nerve damage.
Sudden, painful muscle contractions or spasms.
Uncontrolled muscle spasms on one side of the face.
Unpleasant sensations and leg muscle spasms at rest.
Involuntary muscle contractions leading to abnormal postures.
Swelling and pressure in muscle compartments causing pain and reduced blood flow.
Swelling and bruising of muscles after a direct impact or injury.
Calcification and swelling of muscle tissue following trauma.
Severe muscle breakdown leading to swelling, pain, and kidney damage.
Progressive muscle atrophy and weakness.
Muscle wasting and atrophy are characteristic of this condition.
Muscle and weight loss often seen in advanced cancer or chronic illness.
Muscle atrophy due to nerve damage or disuse.
Degenerative joint disease leading to pain and stiffness.
Inflammatory joint disease causing pain and swelling.
Painful joint inflammation due to uric acid buildup.
Inflammation of fluid-filled sacs causing joint pain.
Swelling of joints is a common symptom.
Joint inflammation and swelling may occur.
Systemic autoimmune disease with joint swelling as a symptom.
Inflammatory arthritis with joint swelling and skin symptoms.
Inflammatory arthritis causing spinal and joint stiffness.
Joint stiffness is common in RA, especially in the morning.
Chronic joint stiffness in children.
Joint stiffness following infections or other triggers.
Loss of joint stability, especially in the knee.
Decreased stability in the knee joint due to PCL injury.
Shoulder joint instability often resulting from a tear.
Joint instability due to increased joint flexibility.
Red and inflamed joints are common in RA.
Acute joint inflammation can cause redness.
Infection leading to red, swollen, and painful joints.
Joint redness and skin changes are characteristic.
Joint deformities are common in severe cases.
Progressive joint degeneration may lead to deformities.
Spinal and joint deformities may occur.
Joint deformities can develop in psoriatic arthritis.
Pain and stiffness result in limited shoulder motion.
Hand condition causing fingers' limited motion.
Joint degeneration restricts motion in affected joints.
Limited hip joint motion due to structural issues.
A bacterial skin infection that results in red sores that can rupture and develop a honey-colored crust.
A fungal infection that leads to a red, circular rash with a raised, scaly border.
A parasitic infection that causes intense itching and a pimple-like rash.
A chronic autoimmune condition characterized by red, scaly skin patches.
Fungal infections like athlete's foot and jock itch can cause itching in affected areas.
Allergic reactions or skin contact with irritants can lead to itching and redness.
Eczema often presents with intense itching and inflamed skin.
Scabies mites burrow under the skin, causing severe itching.
A bacterial skin infection that can cause redness, pain, and warmth in affected areas.
A painful, swollen, and pus-filled lump that forms when an infection causes a pocket of pus to develop.
Herpes can cause painful sores on or around the genitals or mouth.
A viral infection that can lead to a painful rash with blisters.
Swelling and redness are common symptoms of cellulitis, a bacterial skin infection.
Abscesses often result in localized swelling due to the accumulation of pus.
Inflammation of lymphatic vessels can lead to swelling, red streaks, and pain.
A bacterial infection that can cause skin redness, swelling, and fever.
Herpes can lead to painful blisters on or around the genitals or mouth.
Impetigo sores can rupture, forming blisters with a honey-colored crust.
Shingles can cause fluid-filled blisters on the skin.
An autoimmune skin disorder that results in large, fluid-filled blisters.
Dry skin can be caused by environmental factors and may lead to flakiness and itching.
Eczema often results in dry, inflamed, and itchy skin.
Psoriasis can lead to dry, scaly skin patches.
A genetic condition that causes dry, scaly skin.
Psoriasis is known for scaly skin patches with silvery scales.
An inflammatory skin condition that results in red, scaly, and flaky skin.
Ichthyosis can lead to widespread scaling and flaking of the skin.
Dry skin can become scaly and flaky in some cases.
Open sores that typically form on the lower legs and may result from vascular issues.
A rare skin condition causing painful, rapidly developing ulcers.
A parasitic infection that can lead to skin ulcers.
Syphilis can cause painless sores or ulcers in the early stages.
Acne often presents with pustules, papules, and comedones on the skin.
Folliculitis is an infection of the hair follicles, leading to pustules and redness.
Impetigo can result in pustules with a honey-colored crust.
Pyoderma gangrenosum can lead to painful, ulcerating pustules.
Impetigo sores often crust over with a characteristic honey-colored crust.
Scabies can cause crusty, raised burrows on the skin.
Psoriasis plaques may crust over and flake.
Herpes sores can crust over as they heal.
Cellulitis can cause redness and warmth in the affected area.
Erysipelas is characterized by a fiery red rash and raised borders.
Rosacea often leads to facial redness and visible blood vessels.
Eczema can result in red, inflamed patches of skin.
Cellulitis often presents with warmth in the affected skin.
Erysipelas can cause warmth and redness with a well-defined border.
Abscesses may lead to localized warmth, pain, and swelling.
Pyoderma gangrenosum is a painful skin condition with warm, ulcerating areas.
Lipomas are benign lumps made of fatty tissue that can form under the skin.
Boils are painful lumps filled with pus that develop in hair follicles.
A skin condition that leads to painful lumps and abscesses in the armpits and groin.
Erythema nodosum causes painful, red nodules under the skin, often on the shins.
A fungal infection that can lead to patches of lighter or darker skin.
An autoimmune condition that results in the loss of skin color.
Darkening of the skin can occur as a result of healing after inflammation or injury.
A genetic condition causing a complete lack of skin pigmentation.
A condition that leads to hair loss in round, smooth patches on the scalp or elsewhere on the body.
A fungal infection of the scalp that can result in hair loss in affected areas.

conditions.condition: Androgenetic Alopecia (Male or Female Pattern Baldness)
conditions.description: Gradual, age-related hair loss, often due to genetic factors.
Hair loss caused by a significant event, stress, or changes in the hair growth cycle.
Swelling of the deeper layers of the skin, often around the eyes and lips.
Raised, red, itchy welts on the skin, often caused by allergies.
Swelling in the arms or legs due to lymphatic system blockage.
Swelling and redness often occur in response to insect bites.
A chronic condition causing facial redness, visible blood vessels, and red bumps.
Redness and pain due to excessive exposure to UV radiation from the sun.
Red, inflamed patches of skin, often due to allergies.
Red skin rashes are a common symptom of this autoimmune disease.
Papules are a type of acne lesion, small red bumps on the skin.
Infection of hair follicles leads to red, pimple-like papules.
A common skin condition causing small, rough papules on the arms and thighs.
Small, raised papules caused by a viral skin infection.
Darkening of the skin, often due to excess melanin production.
Loss of skin color or lightening, commonly seen in conditions like vitiligo.
Dark patches on the skin, often triggered by hormonal changes.
Moles can be pigmented or non-pigmented and vary in color.
Sudden appearance of itchy, raised welts or hives on the skin.
An itchy skin eruption caused by the varicella-zoster virus.
Reddish-brown skin rash with small, red spots.
Skin reaction to medications, resulting in rashes or eruptions.
Various forms of skin cancer may present as lesions on the skin.
Precancerous skin lesions caused by sun exposure.
A common type of skin cancer characterized by pearly, dome-shaped lesions.
Skin cancer that can manifest as red, scaly lesions.
Small, raised growths on the skin, often with a rough surface.
Warts that develop on the soles of the feet and can be painful.
Warts caused by certain strains of the human papillomavirus (HPV).
Warts that are flat, smooth, and can appear in clusters.
Peeling of the skin is a common aftereffect of sunburn.
A cosmetic procedure that intentionally induces peeling of the skin's outer layer.
A severe skin reaction that can lead to skin peeling and blistering.
A rare and severe skin condition causing widespread peeling and blistering.
Permanent scars left behind after severe acne breakouts.
Scars that result from surgical procedures and vary in appearance.
Raised and thickened scars that can develop after injuries or surgeries.
Scars caused by burns that may be discolored or raised.
Chest pain or discomfort caused by reduced blood flow to the heart muscle.
Severe chest pain resulting from a blocked blood supply to the heart muscle.
Chest discomfort caused by stomach acid flowing back into the esophagus.
Chest pain often due to inflammation of the cartilage that connects ribs to the breastbone.
Difficulty breathing due to the heart's inability to pump blood effectively.
A progressive lung disease that leads to shortness of breath.
Sudden shortness of breath caused by a blood clot in the lungs.
Shortness of breath can be a symptom of anxiety or panic disorders.
Irregular heart rhythm causing palpitations, dizziness, and fatigue.
Fast, irregular heartbeats originating in the heart's lower chambers.
Palpitations due to a heart valve condition affecting the mitral valve.
Rapid heart rate originating above the heart's ventricles.
Extreme tiredness due to the heart's inability to pump blood effectively.
Fatigue resulting from a low red blood cell count, leading to reduced oxygen delivery.
Persistent, unexplained fatigue not improved by rest.
Bone weakening condition that can lead to fatigue and fractures.
Chest pressure or discomfort due to reduced blood flow to the heart muscle.
Inflammation of the sac around the heart can cause chest pressure and pain.
A blood clot in the lung arteries can lead to chest pressure and shortness of breath.
Chest pressure may result from acid reflux.
Leg pain and difficulty walking due to reduced blood flow to the legs.
Joint pain may result in difficulty walking, especially in the knees and hips.
Narrowing of the spinal canal may lead to difficulty walking and leg pain.
Difficulty walking often follows a hip fracture injury.
Tingling or numbness in the extremities due to nerve damage.
Hand numbness and tingling due to pressure on the median nerve in the wrist.
Numbness or tingling on one side of the body can be a sign of a stroke.
Numbness or tingling down the leg due to irritation of the sciatic nerve.
Frequent symptom of viral infections like the common cold.
Inflammation of the bronchial tubes leading to coughing.
Chronic respiratory condition characterized by coughing.
Infection of the lungs causing a productive cough.
Progressive lung disease leading to breathlessness.
Fluid buildup in the lungs causing breathlessness.
Blood clot in the lungs can cause sudden shortness of breath.
Stress and anxiety can lead to shortness of breath.
Constricted airways lead to wheezing sounds.
Wheezing is common in COPD.
Allergic reactions can cause wheezing.
Common in infants, causing wheezing and coughing.
Chest pain due to reduced blood flow to the heart.
Inflammation of the lining around the lungs leading to chest pain.
Infection of the lungs can cause chest pain.
Acid reflux may lead to chest discomfort.
Viral infection causing a sore throat.
Bacterial infection causing severe sore throat.
Inflammation of the voice box results in a sore throat.
Postnasal drip can lead to a sore throat.
Airway constriction can cause chest tightness.
Reflux may lead to a sensation of chest tightness.
Intense anxiety may cause chest tightness.
Chest wall pain can lead to tightness.
Hemoptysis (blood in sputum) is a concerning symptom.
Pulmonary tuberculosis can cause bloody sputum.
Blood in sputum may occur with severe bronchitis.
Blood clot in the lungs may cause hemoptysis.
Acid reflux can cause difficulty swallowing.
Narrowing of the esophagus may lead to swallowing problems.
Neurological conditions can affect swallowing.
Tumors in the throat can cause swallowing difficulties.
Nasal congestion is common with colds.
Allergies can lead to chronic nasal congestion.
Inflammation of the sinuses causes nasal congestion.
Benign growths can obstruct nasal passages.
Intense anxiety can lead to rapid breathing.
Infections can result in rapid, shallow breathing.
Metabolic condition with rapid, deep breathing.
Blood clot in the lungs can cause rapid breathing.
Allergies often cause postnasal drip.
Inflammation of the sinuses can lead to postnasal drip.
Stomach acid reflux into the throat results in postnasal drip.
Infections can cause postnasal drip.
Inflammation of the vocal cords can lead to hoarseness.
Reflux may cause vocal cord irritation and hoarseness.
Thyroid issues can result in hoarseness.
Advanced lung cancer can affect the vocal cords.
Low oxygen levels can cause cyanosis.
Advanced COPD may lead to cyanosis.
Certain heart conditions can cause cyanosis.
Severe bronchitis may result in cyanosis.
Chronic lung disease associated with nail clubbing.
Advanced lung cancer may cause nail clubbing.
Nail clubbing is seen in some forms of ILD.
Rarely, COPD can lead to nail clubbing.
Viral infection causing stridor in children.
Infection leading to stridor and throat swelling.
Inhaling an object can result in stridor.
Severe allergic reaction may cause stridor.
Hemoptysis is a concerning symptom of lung cancer.
Dilated airways can lead to coughing up blood.
Pulmonary tuberculosis may cause hemoptysis.
Blood clot in the lungs can cause hemoptysis.
Long-lasting cough is a symptom of chronic bronchitis.
Persistent cough is common in COPD.
Certain ILDs can lead to chronic cough.
Reflux may cause chronic cough.
Inflammation of the pleura leads to pleuritic chest pain.
Blood clot in the lungs can cause pleuritic pain.
Collapsed lung can result in pleuritic chest pain.
Certain infections may lead to pleuritic pain.
Viral infection in children often leads to noisy breathing.
Infection can cause noisy, labored breathing.
Airway constriction can result in noisy breathing.
Inhaling an object may lead to noisy breathing.
Fluid buildup in the pleural cavity can cause pleural effusion.
Infections can lead to pleural effusion.
Advanced lung cancer may result in pleural effusion.
In some cases, PE can cause pleural effusion.
Green or yellow phlegm is common in bacterial infections.
Inflammation of the bronchial tubes may cause colored phlegm.
Thick, colored mucus is a symptom of CF.
Pus-filled cavity in the lung can lead to colored phlegm.
Fever can be a common symptom of various infections.
High fever is a typical symptom of the flu.
Fever is a key symptom of the coronavirus disease.
Fever is a hallmark symptom of malaria infections.
Fatigue often results from low red blood cell count in anemia.
Persistent, unexplained fatigue not improved by rest.
Fatigue is a common symptom of depression.
Sluggishness and fatigue may be due to an underactive thyroid.
Unexplained weight loss can result from an overactive thyroid.
Unintended weight loss can be an early sign of various cancers.
Conditions like anorexia nervosa can lead to significant weight loss.
Weight loss may be associated with uncontrolled diabetes.
Swelling often caused by fluid retention, kidney, or heart problems.
Autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis can lead to swelling.
Swelling may occur as an allergic reaction, e.g., in angioedema.
Swelling in the limbs due to a blockage in the lymphatic system.
A common type of headache caused by muscle tension.
Severe headaches often accompanied by other symptoms like nausea.
Headaches can result from inflammation of the sinuses.
High blood pressure can lead to recurrent headaches.
Excessive sweating, often unrelated to temperature or exercise.
Hot flashes and night sweats can occur during menopause.
Sweating can be a response to fever in various infections.
Nervousness and anxiety can lead to increased sweating.
A sensation of spinning or unsteadiness often related to inner ear problems.
Dizziness upon standing due to low blood pressure.
Dizziness may result from anemia-related reduced oxygen delivery.
Some migraines include dizziness as a symptom.
Inflammation of the stomach and intestines causing nausea and vomiting.
Nausea commonly experienced during early pregnancy.
Nausea can result from consuming contaminated food.
A side effect of cancer treatment includes nausea.
Irregular heart rhythms can cause palpitations.
Stress and anxiety can lead to palpitations.
Overactive thyroid can cause a rapid heartbeat.
Palpitations may be related to anemia and low oxygen levels.
Joint pain often associated with various forms of arthritis.
Pain can result from physical injuries.
Widespread pain, tenderness, and fatigue characterize fibromyalgia.
Severe pain can be caused by kidney stones.
Weakness and rapid muscle fatigue characterize this autoimmune disorder.
Persistent, unexplained weakness and fatigue.
Various muscle disorders can lead to weakness.
Weakness can result from a lack of essential nutrients.
Excessive bleeding due to a deficiency of clotting factors.
Bleeding from the digestive tract, often due to ulcers or other issues.
Abnormal bleeding can occur in various menstrual conditions.
Low platelet count can lead to bleeding.
Excessive thirst can be a sign of uncontrolled diabetes.
Thirst can result from a lack of fluids in the body.
High blood calcium levels may cause excessive thirst.
Excessive thirst can be a psychiatric symptom.
Blurred vision when looking at distant objects.
Difficulty seeing close-up objects clearly.
Increased intraocular pressure can lead to vision problems.
Loss of central vision due to damage to the macula.
Chest pain caused by reduced blood flow to the heart.
Severe chest pain often accompanied by other symptoms.
Chest pain can be a symptom of acid reflux.
Inflammation of the cartilage connecting the ribs to the breastbone.
Swelling and pain in multiple joints is a hallmark of rheumatoid arthritis.
Sudden and severe joint pain and swelling, often in the big toe.
Progressive joint damage and swelling in osteoarthritis.
Joint swelling can be a symptom of systemic lupus erythematosus.
Common genetic cause of hair loss in both men and women.
Autoimmune condition causing hair loss in patches.
Temporary hair loss often triggered by stress or illness.
Hair loss can result from thyroid problems, both hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism.
